It would be near impossible for Pres. Biden to backtrack and run a conventional campaign. However, if Hillary Clinton was to implode due to damaging revelations with regards to her private email server, then he might "feel the call" to serve his country.  So the question becomes, will Clinton have to halt her campaign before 26 November? A quick glance at two PredictIt polls (see links below) give an average probability of 10%, on a downward trend - I'm taking the average as I'm not convinced the first alone will be sufficient for her to cease her campaign straight away, but both would. I've then divided this by 2 because while there are 2 months left in the year, but one month until the 26th. That's not leaving much of a margin for Biden to decide to run after whatever it is that would bring Clinton down. As we get closer, I'll adjust accordingly. Updating my previous 87% Yes forecast due to new development: Biden is raising an old political issue, the 2011 decision to attack the Abbottabad compound in Pakistan where Bin Laden was hiding. 
http://www.politico.com/story/2015/10/joe-biden-support-bin-laden-raid-214954
Logic: 
1. Biden is deliberately raising a contentious, murky issue - whether he supported the raid in 2011 - that is of no relevance to any current decision or policy matter.  
2. Biden is therefore raising this moot, dead issue for some kind of political purpose. Why now? Why this issue? Because it draws a contrast between the VP and the then-Secretary of State. That would be Hillary Clinton. 
3. What is that contrast? Biden deliberately leaves the actual decision in a gray area, repeatedly framing it as "49 [% vs.] 51 [%]". The only real difference between his view and those of the other cabinet officials is their _relationship to the president_. Biden was in a superior, more intimate, more powerful and influential position than any other Cabibet member.
4. Biden explicitly says that his motivation was to support the president.  Biden's hidden messages here are clear: unlike Hillary, I, the Vice President, have actually been tested for the presidency, on an issue that - unlike Benghazi - was a huge triumph for the administration.  And unlike the Clintons, I am the true supporter, and the natural heir to the legacy, of Barack Obama. Biden is all but certain to announce soon. His campaign strategy is becoming clear: he will contrast his experience, judgment and depth (cf his skill and correct judgments regarding the post-Saddam Iraqi government) with Hillary's very mixed - arguably, quite weak - performance as Secretary of State.

1. Ambition: Biden is an intensely ambitious man whose sole objective has been the presidency. Evidence: Biden is the only U.S. senator who has never accumulated a fortune; never sought or received a lucrative private equity/investment or consulting or lobbying position; never sought to cash in on his fame via five- or six-figure lectures or million-dollar book royalties, or any other profit-seeking venture. He is 100% a political animal, perhaps the last remaining such figure in our national political life.
2. He has plenty of time to win: the notion that it's too late to enter and win is unsupported by logic or evidence. First, Biden's campaign apparatus can easily and rapidly raise money, and in any case his name recognition is already high enough that he needs less advertising spend than any other candidate, in either party.  Secondly, it is the Democratic Party's superdelegates, not the Party rank-and-file voters, who determine the nominee. These are ruthlessly pragmatic professionals who simply want to win the presidency. Most have no particular loyalty to the Clintons. More than a few are intensely loyal to Obama, and still harbor bitter feelings over the 2008 race. These superdelegates would gladly switch to Obama's most loyal ally (and his likely designated heir).
3. Biden's model here is Bobby Kennedy (RFK), another high-profile executive branch figure who jumped into the race in March 1968 and quickly vaulted to the forefront - even though Kennedy was a far more divisive and controversial figure. Like Biden, RFK had zero interest in money and was motivated instead by lifelong, burning ambition, stoked in part by personal resentment of a Democratic rival. Biden probably does not resent the Clintons to anywhere near the degree that RFK hated Lyndon Johnson, but he is a politician through and through. Biden knows that he is a far better politician than Hillary Clinton and that he was the force behind most of the major achievements of the Obama administration (including the extraordinarily successful rescue of GM, the prevention of financial collapse, and the passage of the stimulus bill in the face of Republican obstructionism). The party's superdelegates also know that Hillary is a weak candidate with no better than a 50-50 chance of defeating Rubio or Bush, both of whom Biden would easily defeat through a combination of very high African-American turnout and white working-class support across Ohio, the rest of the industrial heartland and the other battleground states. 
Biden wants the presidency, and he will announce well before Thanksgiving. 75% odds that he announces by noontime ET Monday Nov. 2.

Biden waited, and waited, and waited, and by the time he announced his decision not to run in August 2003, he declared: "You just can't parachute into a presidential campaign."  . . .  "In other words, what we are witnessing is a rerun, even with a strange and unhappy similarity in that there was a key family reason . . .  that impacted the decision. Many concluded in the aftermath of the 2003-2004 episode that Biden never intended to run, but that he enjoyed the limelight and attention (no surprise there, and certainly nothing unique to him), and waited as long as he reasonably could play the game, only to wisely declare that it simply was too late.
. . .
". . .  when he declares that he will not run, it [appearances of campaign planning] will turn out to have been no more real than it was a dozen years ago. So, my first projection was pulled out of my you-know-what and based almost totally on the esteem I hold Nate Silver and fivethirtyeight.com.  Now that I've given it more thought, here's my rational for this adjustment: Pro - 1. Veeps running is a thing. Since the end of WW2, nine of thirteen Veeps have run for President, which would give us a base rate of 70%. I've discounted it 12% because three of them became Presidents due to the resignation or death of the sitting President, then ran. So 58% percent in the go column. 2. The guy's run twice before, and past behaviour counts, to a degree. Give it 10%. 3. Positive media attention does have an impact, but I don't think it's anywhere near what people think. 5%. 4. Rumours and innuendo can't be discounted entirely. Another 5%. Total in the Pro column: 78% Con - 1. Per Nick Silver, with almost all the major party endorsements to date for Clinton ( http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-endorsement-primary/ ) you've got an establishment guy going against the establishment's choice. Big 50% agin. 2. Why? Without Clinton truly imploding, and with no fundamental policy differences between them, or a disenfranchised part of the party to speak for (unlike Sanders) he has no compelling reason TO run. At least 10% against. 3. Legacy. The man is seventy and looking at the end of his career. I don't think he wants his last hurrah to be the spoiler hurting the presumptive nominee. Another 10% against. 4. Highly unlikely chance of winning. Latecomers to the race rarely win the nomination, and even if he did, just because Veeps run (see item 1 in the Pro column above) definitely doesn't mean they win. If you discount the guys that won because they became President first (Johnson, Truman) and the guy who won after he spent eight years in the woods (Nixon) only one Vice President has won the Presidency right after being Veep - George HW Bush. That said, its not  like the unlikelihood of winning stopped Biden before (see item 2 in the Pro column). Give it 5%. Total in the Con column - 75% So, 78% - 75% makes for 3% chance he'll actually run is my thinking. :-) Rob

"Mrs. Clinton would still be, by any measure, the candidate in the best position to win the nomination. She also has an advantage over Mr. Biden across every dimension of primary strength. She has more endorsements, fund-raising and elite support. She leads him in every poll, in every state, across every demographic group. At the moment, the likeliest outcome would be that Mr. Biden wins zero states. "There are few reasons to believe that Mr. Biden is such a compelling political figure that he could simply snatch away Mrs. Clinton’s coalition. He twice ran for the presidency with little success. He was vice president for eight years, but there was not a groundswell of support for him to join the race. He may be riding high in recent polls, but sustaining high favorability ratings after jumping into the fray and becoming a more politicized figure could very well be a different story. He would face attacks about his long and often fairly moderate record in the Senate, on issues like crime, finance or Iraq. "The challenge is even greater because Mr. Sanders has already consolidated much of Mrs. Clinton’s natural opposition, and it is a stretch to suggest that Mr. Biden — an establishment Democrat with a record not that different from Mrs. Clinton’s — would have a real chance of peeling away Mr. Sanders’s enthusiastic and loyal supporters. "But unlike Mr. Sanders, Mr. Biden is acceptable to party elites, and nearly all Democratic voters see him as “electable.” He is well known and liked by less-educated and more moderate Democrats, and his relationship to Mr. Obama could ultimately help among black voters as well. "If Mrs. Clinton faltered, which is imaginable as long as the email controversy lingers, Mr. Biden would be poised to capitalize. Just as Mrs. Clinton is the second choice of Biden supporters, Mr. Biden is the second choice of Clinton supporters. "The scenario in which Mrs. Clinton implodes and leaves Mr. Biden to a one-on-one contest with Mr. Sanders is unlikely. But Mr. Biden would be the favorite in that event, even if he had to make up ground against Mr. Sanders in fund-raising and organization. A YouGov poll showed Mr. Biden leading Mr. Sanders by a 58-to-42 margin in a one-on-one contest — even though he would trail Mr. Sanders in a three-way race — by claiming most of Mrs. Clinton’s support among older and nonwhite voters. "A more likely possibility than a Clinton implosion is that she has been more deeply damaged by the email controversy than currently believed or will be hurt by future developments. In that case, Mr. Biden’s presence would allow Democratic elites to bail out on her, rather than trying to shore up her campaign, knowing they had an acceptable and electable alternative. "Mrs. Clinton would still be very difficult to defeat, thanks to her substantial resources and strong base, and it could lead to something like a true three-way race. Even if Mr. Biden couldn’t ultimately defeat Mrs. Clinton, he would make her path to victory much longer.
. . . 
"What we know for sure is that Mrs. Clinton would start a three-way race with a big edge, and that Mr. Biden is the type of candidate who would have a chance of taking that advantage for himself if she ran into more trouble. And if he doesn’t run? She goes back to being an overwhelming favorite for the nomination. His decision is easily the most important political story of the moment.

http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/a-new-clue-suggests-biden-may-run "Joe Biden has taken another step toward entering the Presidential race. "Representatives of the Vice-President held a meeting this week with Democratic National Committee staffers. They briefed Biden’s aides on arcane but crucial rules that the Vice-President would need to understand if he decides to run, according to a D.N.C. official. "It was the most significant sign the source had seen to indicate Biden’s intentions. “I think it means he’s running,” the source said. ". . . D.N.C. staffers walked Biden’s representatives through the primary calendar, filing deadlines, the mechanics of ballot-access issues, and the complicated details of the party’s state-by-state selection process for delegates and super delegates. The session included a level of detail that would only be of interest to a candidate who is serious about running. For example, the briefing included information about issues such as whether a particular primary state requires a candidate to send a letter to the Secretary of State in order to get on the ballot, or circulate a petition, or pursue some other method. "But, while the briefing is considered an important step for any candidate who is serious about entering the race, how it will affect Biden’s decision is unclear. It may simply be that Biden is still gathering the necessary information to help him make a final determination. And the details of the complicated process of winning enough delegates to secure his party’s nomination might convince Biden that the window to enter the race has passed. "The D.N.C. source, who was briefed on the meeting, said that the information conveyed seemed eye-opening for Biden’s aides. “They probably thought they had a lot longer,” the source said. “The deadlines for qualifying on the ballots for key states haven’t passed yet, but are fast approaching.”
~~~~~~~

U.S. News reported in June that a decision would come by the end of July. CNN reported that advisers had instructed him to choose whether to run by the end of September. In August, the Associated Press reported that a decision was coming after a weeklong retreat with his family; two weeks later, the AP reported that he would make a decision by Oct. 1. In September, the Wall Street Journal said a decision could come "well into the fall." This week, CBS News reported that he could come down one way or another within seven to 10 days. At some point along the way, it became clear that things weren't moving as quickly as envisioned, which prompted Salon to run a piece in late September titled "What is Taking Joe Biden So Long?" This week, the Washington Post's Dana Milbank lampooned the "never-ending" Biden delay. Google the phrase "Will he or won't he," and you'll find a Weekly Standard article on Biden from April, a Politico item from August, an MSNBC segment from a few weeks later and a Washington Post article from October. The Post followed up that article Wednesday by polling readers about whether or not they think the VP will run. (and the closing paragraph) Biden may decide not to throw his hat in the ring at all. - Biden faces some complex issues entering the race this late. As a short-term matter, he faces a timing issue. The first debate is on the 13th; he will not participate. He could announce just before the debate, which would capture attention at the expense of him being called out for skipping the first debate. His best bet is probably to announce the day after the debate, allowing him to seize the news cycle and maintain a hook -- "I watched Hilary and Sanders debate, and neither of them spoke to my issues, so I'm running."
- Fundamentally this is a personal decision, the hardest to predict. Biden is unconstrained. He is the Vice President, but he is 72 years old. No one would blame him for bowing out. He can run, or not, and the main reasons for doing so are entirely inside his head.

This is a difficult one to call as while historically most incumbent Vice Presidents have sought the nomination when their President retires there have been exceptions (most recently Cheney) and Biden could easily join the ranks of the exceptions. Having already sought the nomination twice it seems likely to me that he would only make a third attempt if he thought the odds were significantly in his favour and so the question is will the decline in Clinton's fortunes reach a point where Biden believes he has a better than even chance of defeating her? Clinton is undoubtedly a weak favourite in that any other credible challenger entering the race could lead to a run on her support and given reports of defections from some of her supporters to "draft Biden" groups and the fact that she is apparently burning through money at a prodigious rate it seems likely that the slow drift away from her in the polls will continue but whether it will drift enough for Biden by the end of November is another question. Therefore while I am far from certain Biden will run I believe the lure of one final attempt plus the weakness in Clinton's support will tempt him to take the plunge.

Counter arguments to one I've already presented . . . 
 My observation is that people who run for office generally are people-pleasers.  
Biden may honestly be plumbing the depths of his ambition and energy, but we shouldn't discount the pressure that political operatives can bring to bear on a person. I have seen up close how people near a potential candidate can push/pressure them into running  even though their heart really isn't in to it:  how they agree to run because they think that not running would mean letting down their supporters. Who is yelling at him these days?  His fans, and they're saying, "Run, Joe, Run!"   Where is the pressure coming from:  those who want him to run.  The only significant counter pressure would be coming from his family and those who think he has too much to lose, and possibly Democratic party operatives who don't want him muddying up the waters on the D side. Also, much was made last night on Charlie Rose of Biden's references on Stephen Colbert's show to the ethos of "just getting up". . . Fighting on when one doesn't feel like it.  He may feel that to not run is to fail to "just get up".  So, will he listen to himself?  and what part of himself will he listen to:  his grieving heart or his dutiful mind?   Or will he listen to political operatives?   Who will he try to please?  When his wife & daughter died and both his sons were injured, and he was considering resigning from the Senate, he listened to operative rather than his own heart and didn't resign.
I have the inkling that Biden is not going to run finally. Let's see what happens.

This question was the subject of a 20-min conversation on Charlie Rose last night.  One thing that I got out of the program was that November 1st was "very late", so I assume Thanksgiving is "extremely late".  That means that this question is likely to either close early as "Yes" or resolve as "no" on Nov 26.  If it resolves early as "yes", there may be no chance to adjust forecasts accordingly, so an extreme "no" forecast could really hurt. Another thing that I got  out of the program is that those who love Biden are concerned about what it would do to him to jump into the race thus truncating his mourning, take the psychological beating that a campaign always entails, and then lose.  They point out that he is at an all-time high in terms of popularity, and that the scenario just described above would be a devastating blow that would then turn the narrative of his life into one about a man who ran for the presidency 3x and failed.  I think all these folks who run for high office care about their "legacy".  With Hillary having so much locked up, and Biden having a hard time revving himself up for the campaign, I think that arguments along these lines would sway him to stay out. Nate Silver wrote a good piece about this in August: http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/joe-bidens-potential-2016-presidential-campaign/
Excerpts:
But here’s the dilemma: The longer Biden waits to officially enter the race, the more of a problem his late start would become. He couldn’t easily make up for lost fundraising opportunities, for example. And at some point — likely in mid-November — he’d begin to encounter logistical challenges, like having failed to meet the filing deadline in New Hampshire and other early states. At the same time, Biden has little rationale to enter the race this late except as a break-glass-in-case-of-Clinton-emergency candidate. His formal entry into the race would imply that Clinton’s campaign was under serious threat. The party establishment, most of which is extremely supportive of Clinton, wouldn’t like the signal that sends out. But one detail that made it into several of these stories is that he plans to wait until September to make any decision. Although there are other plausible explanations, the simplest one is that Biden is biding his time, waiting as long as possible to see if Clinton is in more trouble than she appears to be right now.
~~~~~~~~

~~

As a result, I'm very bearish on Biden jumping in.
